indicators.justification:
Information on  emissions about the country is  available on the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change website as well as the local UNDP Office. The latest report for Namibia  filed February 2021, if for the content covering until the year 2016 making such information 5 years old. This report is however only available only in a PDF format and does not allow a user to explore back and forth. 

Such information did not require AI and Machine learning for reading purpose. The report is available as a PDF format through a web-upload  and it is not user friendly hence can't meet the requierement of the open data framework. 
However such dataset meeting all Open Data definitions is availed by private institution Knoema and all data about Namibia's emissions are also available there.
Hence we conclude that through govt action information is available NOT as OPEN DATA, while an open data set if available but not through governments action.

Source: 
1. United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, Namibia Fourth Biennial Update Report (BUR4) to the United Nations Framework Convention
on Climate Change available here https://unfccc.int/sites/default/files/resource/Namibia-BUR4-FINAL.pdf

2. Environmental Information Service Namibia available at http://the-eis.com/elibrary/sites/default/files/downloads/literature/Fourth%20national%20communication%20to%20the%20United%20Nations%20Framework%20Convention%20on%20Climate%20Change.pdf

evidence.title: Fourth Biennial Update Report (BUR4) to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

indicators.justification:
Information about Namibia's endagered species and ecosystem  is available as open data through the Namibia Bio Diversity website which, as per their claim is informed by information from the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) that maintains the global Red List of Threatened Species. As known , the Government of Namibia, through the Ministry of Environment and Tourism, is a member of IUCN.

This information  is available in PDF and in bulk as CSV format and an internet interface. 

In conclusion the data available on Namibias endangered specials and ecosystem is available as open data but not as a result of government action.

indicators.justification:
The data available regarding Namibia climate vulnerability information is dated 2010 and is available through govt's action. However this information is not available in bulk format or interactive interfaces but only on PDF format making it difficult to engage with it back and forth easily or does it  In that allow for one to assess over a time.

Hence we conclude that the  climate vulnerability information availability  as open data is not met or at least only by 20% as more value for PDF version.

responses.subquestion_text: Is the data restricted to a particular sector? Or does it have broad coverage of companies in the country?

indicators.justification:
The public search dataset via BIPA website (the only search available producing dataset immediately for external usage) doesn't provide much information about the ownership of the businesses beyond the (Registration N, 	Company Name, Date Registered	and Status). 
This dataset doesn't say anything about about the ownership of the company from an open data concept. A research article by the Institute for Public Policy  Research further indicates the challenges with datasets available when data is requested by users and went on to make further recommendations that "The Business and Intellectual Property Authority (BIPA) should make every effort to maintain a complete and updated company registration database" 
Given researchers observation results of this research,  the company information available as structured open data in Namibia is perhaps at 5% at very least extent.

Source: 
IPPR, 2020, Red Flags -The warning signs fluttering over emergency procurement practices available at https://ippr.org.na/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Red-flags-web.pdf

evidence.title: Red Flags - The warning signs fluttering over emergency procurement practices

indicators.justification:
The national civil registration and vital statistics (CRVS) information available is not available to the public as as open data.

However  civil registration and vital statistics (CRVS) dataset  include 
-Town/ Region/  causes of death

- and Birth information  include the details about the child, the birth, parents, and the registration process. 

However this information are not available in an interoperable systems. 

Source: 

Ministry of Home Affairs, Department of Civil Registration Services, https://mha.gov.na/web/mhai/civil-registration-services

indicators.justification:
While internal systems to centralise data and ease of access throughout at  point of service can be seen as a positive development in this regard, the fact that this data is not available to the public to explore does not answer to the openness of the data. 
Additionally the Ministry is using 2  different databases for the types of land usage, one for Deeds office  which concentrate on commercial land and the other  for Communal Land which would indicate an ununiformity of datasets.

Sources: 
1. Mr Peter Shivute  
Project Manager: Communal Land Registration 
Ministry of Agriculture, Water and Land Reform

indicators.justification:
Government budget and spending information (budget execution) is available on a website in a dataset that indicates the recieving O/M/A and the amount thereof. 
However, this data is not presented according to Administrative classification as guided by the IMF guidelines. 

available as structured open data?

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.

There is structured data available on amended budgets (when applicable) or amendments of the enacted budget.
There is structured data available on the approved or enacted budget in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about government budget execution or spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis, including spending in annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about the government's extrabudgetary funds spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about the government's social security spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about public corporations' spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.

Budget entries have economic classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.
Information about individual financial transactions or expenditures is available at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification level.

The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.

indicators.justification:
The latest Asset register for Parliamentarians was released in 2020, however it was conclusive as reported by the New Era with many parliamentarians not filling it out at all. 
Previously the Namibian Newspaper has  reported in 2018 that An updated register of MPs' assets has not been publicly available since 2009. 
Source: 
1. The Namibia (2018) https://www.namibian.com.na/174398/archive-read/Katjavivi-fails-assets-transparency-test--as-lawmakers-disregard-rules
2. New Era Newspaper (2020) https://neweralive.na/posts/mps-make-mockery-of-asset-declaration

indicators.justification: There is no law or regulations requiring public consultations. While the country have embedded public consultations as part of law making process, data on these exercises are not available. Many times the members of the public have bemoaned that the public consultation is a box ticking exercise that doesn't take serious input from Civil Society as their inputs are largely lacking  in the final drafts.

indicators.justification:
Governments contracts for the provision of goods, services, and public are published through a  government procurement progress plan of the Ministry of Finance that has now also be transferred to the Public Procurement Board. A data set is available at the Ministry of  finance web platform until 2019 via the link https://mof.gov.na/documents/35641/36535/QUARTERLY+RETURN+ON+PROCUREMENT+ACTIVITIES+February+2019.pdf/e6722d54-2f16-67f3-ab57-cb049f87d90c
 and now at the Public Procument Board via this link https://www.cpb.org.na/index.php/awards with the latest awarded tenders recorded of October 2021. 

However the data set dates  does not allow someone to track back the information for an extended period and demonstrate the openness of the system

Regardless of the state of undauntedness. The reports includes the following data sets 
"(a)Procurement Reference No.
(b) Procurement Description
(c) Category
(d) Procurement Method (RB, RFQ and RFP)
(e) Date Contract Awarded
(f) Name of Successful Bidder(s)
(h) Amount Paid (N$)" Ministry of Finance.

Its important to note that such data isn't available in csv format to allow exploring of dataset nor the bulk data set available through an API. 

Hence it is safe to conclude that the data assessed covers a very limited number of public procurements and few other sources of data are available and this indicator as Open Data data is minimally met if at all.

Sources: 
1. Central Procurement Board of Namibia, Awarded tenders, https://www.cpb.org.na/index.php/awards

responses.subquestion_text: This information is missing required data.

responses.response_text: The data assessed covers a very limited number of public procurements and few other sources of data are available.
responses.subquestion_text: How comprehensive is the data assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
There is isolated case of a government project called X-road that amongst others aims to encourage data sharing and re-use since 2015. 

But there are no laws governing this and this project has not entirely been reported to be successful. 

Hence the extend is very little and isolated of which government provides support for data reuse is known and undocumented. But given the lack of laws the largely mistrust understood to be existing between O/M/As in regards to data sharing and reuse, we conclude that there are no efforts. 

Cases of  hackathons have been reported by the media most of which  takes place in the city, Windhoek only and are rarely reported out of town and many if not all are efforts of private and development sector. 

Datas used for these is mostly provided by private sector. 

There is no  evidence in place of a government strategy to support and encourage data reuse through plans, policies, actions, initiatives, and other events.

responses.response_text: There is isolated evidence of government supporting and encouraging data reuse.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of a government strategy to support and encourage data reuse?
There is evidence of government efforts to support open government data reuse.
There is evidence of government efforts to support big data reuse in a general sense.
There is evidence of government efforts to support private sector or NGO data reuse.
There is evidence of government efforts to support crowdsourced data reuse.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse from various data topics.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by civil society organizations.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by media.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by scholars and academic institutions.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by the private sector.
Government support for data reuse involves data challenges.
Government support for data reuse involves hackathons.
Government support for data reuse involves communication and community building efforts.
Government support for data reuse involves running information sessions on how to use particular datasets, or how to reuse government data in general.
Government support for data reuse involves the release of funding schemes

responses.response_text: Support is given in one or more localities, but there are many other localities without such support, or with support of a lesser quality.
responses.subquestion_text: How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the support assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
The country has no well-resourced open government data initiative, pronouncement, action, activities, publications or portal. 
While for instance through the Public Procurement Act, regular publication of government spending is required to be published regularly. The reports are not always upto data and they are only available through PDF format which while it is a machine readable format, it is not computed through machine learning nor is artificial intelligence used  to document the data.

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of any government-led open government data initiative in the country.
responses.subquestion_text: Has there been any form of government-led open government data initiative during the study period?
There is a government team in place supporting open data activities.
There is an allocated budget for open data activities.
There is a well-maintained open data portal.
There is guidance and support for government publication of open data.
Senior political leaders back the open data initiative.

indicators.justification:
This indicator is not applicable as the extent  of city, regional, and local governments  capability to effectively manage data in the context of open data through is indicator doesn't  fit the existing frameworks. 
The practice is that local governments like most government agencies owns and provide services through digital systems, such as the water Billings and others. So far no leakage of this data has been reported and hence it can be presumed to be effective. 
however there are no indications that the local governments  provides local open data initiatives that encourage users to  "learn how to use open government values such as transparency, accountability, responsiveness, and inclusion to better meet the needs of the citizens they serve." as guided by this indicator.

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of capability to effectively manage data.
responses.subquestion_text: To what extent do city, regional, and local governments have the capability to effectively manage data?
There is evidence of local governments having open data initiatives.
There is evidence of local governments having current open data policies in place.
There is evidence of local governments having rules and or guidance in place to provide a comprehensive framework for data sharing.
There is evidence of local governments having rules and or guidance in place for consistent data management and publication.
There is evidence of local governments providing training to civil servants on data literacy and skills.
There is evidence of local governments providing support for data reuse.

indicators.justification:
This is one of the isolated cases under which government trainings on data is targeted to Civil servants has been reported.  However it is fair to assume that government in general have been rolling out training for officials on data Maning since data has increasingly become a large part of the government business.
Additionally a new Revenue Agency was recently launched during the years under review, and in particular is enforcing  Online filing of taxations, this means that new data skills had to be developed 

Sources: 

1. Namibia Statistics Agency, 2020, available at https://d3rp5jatom3eyn.cloudfront.net/cms/assets/documents/Media_statement_Covid_Hub1.pdf
2. New Era Newspaper, (2019) Recruitment Agency to commence soon,  https://neweralive.na/posts/recruitment-for-revenue-agency-to-commence-soon

indicators.justification: The data sets associated with this theme are quite different. The data set between the parliamentary asset register and the regulations of political funding use very limited common identifiers as one is seeking transparency and accountability at individual level and the other is seeking at party level.

responses.response_text: The datasets use a limited number of common identifiers.
responses.subquestion_text: There is evidence that datasets share common identifiers.
The key datasets for this theme share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The different political integrity datasets use common identifiers for public officials.
Lobbying data and political finance data share common identifiers for lobbyist clients and party and campaign donors.
Lobbying registers and public consultation data use common identifiers for regulations.
Asset declarations and political finance disclosures share common identifiers for interests, assets, and liabilities.
The various datasets share common identifiers for legal persons associated with donations, interests, assets, liabilities, and lobbying activities.
The key datasets for the political integrity and company information modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and land modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public finance modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public procurement modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.

indicators.justification:
The relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance as listed and attached, provides a basis for collecting and publishing beneficial ownership data on companies.
Such as Section 5 of the Close Corporation Act that deals with "Inspection and copies of documents in Registration Office"
Section 10 of the Companies Act of 2004 deals with "Annual report by Registrar"  that deals with publication of data, which should entail information about shareholders and the management of the company. 
The Business and Intellectual Property Authority Act of 2016 is responsible for the the registration of business and intellectual properties which includes  "maintain accurate, current and relevant information concerning business and intellectual property". 
These laws that provides basis for collecting  of the data however the publishing part of the information has not been strongly adhere to.  
The company register and the data related to ownership is open to the public upon request of specific information in writing by the media or other regulatory/judicial authority.
This indicator can be said to have been met at 50%

Definitions comprehensively cover ownership.
Definitions cover control.

indicators.justification:
There is an indication that to a large extend the National laws, policies and guidance requires that data collection and publication be accessible to people with disabilities and efforts exists from the past that the following documents have been published in braille; The Constitution of Namibia, the Baseline report on Development Goals, MVA fund, HIV/AIDS  issue (Newsletter) for May-July 2015. 
No evidence has indicated that the National Census have never been printed in brialle for accessibility at least not within the period under review.

indicators.justification:
The extent where  relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provides a comprehensive framework for consistent data management and publication is non-existent. 
The emphasis is comprehensive framework. An access to information law has been in draft form and has gone to parliament and back to consultations over periods of time, however this is not in place yet. 
Other isolated relations too exists requiring consistent data management and publication however inconstencies exists over the publication period, format and accessibility such as the Procurement reports by the Ministry of Finance.

evidence.title: Data Collection, Processing and Dissemination Policy and Practice  of 2014

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
There are minimum standards for metadata when government data is catalogued or published.
There is a standardised process for publishing and updating published government data.
There are technical standards, including common data models, codelists, and identifiers for management and publication of government data.
There are clearly documented quality control processes for government data.
There are clearly documented processes for soliciting and integrating feedback from external users to improve data quality.

indicators.justification:
Nothing much came out of this  proposed action  (e-Government Strategic Action Plan of the Public Service of Namibia (2014–2018)) An update from the office of the prime minister read " GRN e-Governance Project Current Status. The project was initiated in February 2010. The consultants assigned to the project are from SILNAM IT Solutions. The first phase of the project was to assess the readiness of the Government of Namibia to embark on the E-Governance journey. To accomplish that, the consultant and the project team had consulted OMAs, businesses and communities as well as conducting surveys through the means of questionnaires." and does not provide further information on this status. Most importantly this does not speak to data sharing. it is available here 
Source 
https://opm.gov.na/e-governance

evidence.title: e-Government Strategic Action Plan of the Public Service of Namibia (2014–2018)

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
The framework covers data sharing within government.
The framework covers how government should share data with other sectors.
The framework covers data sharing from other sectors to government.
The framework covers data sharing within the private sector.
The framework explicitly focuses on artificial intelligence uses of data.

indicators.justification:
Different, isolated framework on data protection of personal data exists in different sectors according to DLA Piper, a global law firm operating through various separate and distinct legal entities.To a certain extent that protection held water until the digital evolution where the application of data protection online isn't guaranteed under existing laws and does not comprehensively offer protection personal data anymore. 

Hence, the extent of the relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance do not provide a comprehensive framework for protection of personal data in a digital age and doesn't comprehend/promote operations under the open data framework.

responses.response_text: A framework exists but lacks full force of law.
responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
The framework provides data subjects with rights of choice or consent.
The framework provides data subjects with rights to access and correct data about themselves.
The framework sets out clear responsibilities for data holders.
The framework provides rights of redress
The framework requires data controllers to notify an appropriate authority of data breaches.
Frameworks explicitly cover the protection of location-related data.
The framework addresses algorithmic decision making.
Exceptions to the usual data protection framework have been made as part of the country's COVID-19 response.

responses.response_text: The framework applies widely across all sectors (including public and private sector).

responses.response_text: The framework assessed, or equivalent frameworks, apply across the whole country.

indicators.justification:
There is a large extent of relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance that requires  data collection and publication processes be available in the country's official as indicated by  Article 3 (1) of the Constitution that reads the  official language of Namibia shall be English. 
Additionally, the Namibia Broadcasting Act of 1991, in its objective reads "3. The objectives of the Corporation shall be to carry on a broadcasting service in order to ­(d) to promote the use and understanding of the English language."
This is regarded as the language of service in Namibia.

indicators.justification: A framework on Open Data and its principles has not been mentioned in Namibia at this point. Hence this indicator does applying Namibia.

Laws, regulations  assessed for this indicators provides basis for publishing data on public finances (E.g., government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing. 
Annually a Budget Plan for the year is tabled and published in parliament and available online as in this year's case available here https://mof.gov.na/documents/35641/36583/Budget+Statement+2021_22.pdf/356d55a3-c7d5-fef1-941c-528b1baa787e as requirement by the State Finance Act.

indicators.justification:
There are no laws in place that provides for a basis for collecting and publishing data generated through and about public consultation on rulemaking. 

However the norms have become that, public consultations on policies or regulations is required as a law making process however its important to note that this is not a constitutional or required legislative measure. 

This indicator is not applicable.

indicators.justification:
On 17 June 2020 – Exactly four years after the initial draft was created, The Minister of Information and communication Technology  Peya Mushelenga tabled the long-awaited Access to Information Bill in the National Assembly. National consultation on the bill is happening throughout the country. However the Bill is not yet available to the public

The bill has not been passed by parliament and is currently not available for review as it is apparentlyat the house of Review the National Council. 
As of September 2021, UNESCO, the Internet Society Namibia Chapter as well as the Ministry of ICT have been embarked on National Consultations on the Access to Information Bill. This exercise is still ongoing.

Source: 
1. Fact Check Namibia (2020) TIMELINE: Namibia's journey to an access to information law available at TIMELINE: Namibia's journey to an access to information law
2. Zimbabwe Herald (2020) Namibia Tables Bill on acmes to information - available at  https://www.herald.co.zw/namibia-tables-bill-on-access-to-information/

evidence.title: TIMELINE: Namibia’s journey to an access to information law

indicators.justification:
In April 2021,  Namibia's Minister of Defence resigned over allegations of corruption as information tied to his oversees account and a 13 year old case on an arms deal reveals his hands aren't clean. 

His case followed in the heals of the biggest corruption scandal that has landed former cabinet Ministers in prison following an internationally coordinated investigation into data and financial dealings related to the allocation of fishing quotas in the country. 

These two case highlight how data is being used to ensure or prove political integrity in the country. While these cases can be heralded, they are few and isolated.

evidence.title: Former Namibian Minister Arrested after Aljazeera investigations
Fire! Then What? - As Defence Minister steps down
Hong Kong account haunts defence minister

The media regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
Scholars or academic institutions regularly use this data for accountability purposes.

At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data

indicators.justification:
There are no evidence of interactive dashboards that report basic statistics such as procurement spend by department or category, the kinds of procurement processes used, and the length of time each process has taken.
Additionally, there are no evidence on government procurement data being used for red flag analysis as such there no public online tools used to perform red flag analysis,  however  the below research analysis indicates its own 'red flags" during the COVID-19 state-of-emergency period  and identified these 'red flags' as concerningly visible on the public procurement landscape such as 
• Short tender periods;
• Very few bidders, or just one bidder, invited to tender;
• Few or no contracts awarded competitively;
• Unclear or inaccessible company registration and/or ownership information.
Source:
1. IPPR (2020) "Pandemic Procurement – Red Flags Fluttering Procurement Tracker Namibia Special Report" https://ippr.org.na/publication/pandemic-procurement-red-flags-fluttering/
2. IPPR (2020)"Red Flags' The warning signs fluttering over emergency procurement practices" available at https://ippr.org.na/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Red-flags-web.pdf

As an addition, evidence on government procurement data being analysed to improve access to procurement opportunities for marginalised groups or to support sustainable / environmental procurement  or  according to the Government progress report  on procurrement of 2019 as available here https://mof.gov.na/documents/35641/36535/QUARTERLY+RETURN+ON+PROCUREMENT+ACTIVITIES+February+2019.pdf/e6722d54-2f16-67f3-ab57-cb049f87d90c
Most importantly, there are no examples of the Open Data portal or online tools available that indicates the use of artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data or conduct an analysis.

evidence.title: Pandemic Procurement red flags fluttering
evidence.link: 1. IPPR 2020 "Pandemic Procurement – Red Flags Fluttering Procurement Tracker Namibia Special Report" https://ippr.org.na/publication/pandemic-procurement-red-flags-fluttering/

responses.response_text: There is evidence of isolated uses or pilot projects.
responses.subquestion_text: To what extent is there evidence of this kind of data use?
There is evidence of government procurement data being presented through data-driven dashboards.
There is evidence of government procurement data being used for red flag analysis.
There is evidence that government procurement data is being analyzed to improve access to procurement opportunities for marginalized groups.
There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.
There are examples of government using data in these ways.
There are examples of civil society using data in these ways.
There is evidence of private sector using data in this way
At least one of the examples cited appears to make use of open procurement data.
At least one of the examples identified makes use of open beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

indicators.indicator_name: Capability (C): Political freedoms and civil liberties
Capability (C): Business use of digital tools
Capability (C): Use of standards and methods in statistic offices
Use (U): Data use by international organizations
